clinical_study.brief_title: Physiologic MR Imaging of Salivary Gland Tumors
clinical_study.official_title: Physiologic MR Imaging in Distinguishing Benign From Malignant Salivary Gland Tumors

lead_sponsor.agency: Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania

clinical_study.source: Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to use advanced Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) techniques to help identify the difference between cancerous and non-cancerous salivary gland tumors for improving treatment strategies and to aid in the prediction of disease progression.

detailed_description.textblock: The goal of this study is to investigate the potential utility of combined analysis of parameters (Ktrans, ti and ADC) in discriminating benign from malignant salivary glands tumors (SGTs). A total of 30 treatment na√Øve patients suspicious of SGT as observed on clinical evaluation and prior routine CT/MRI will undergo 3T MRI. The MRI protocol will include acquisition of anatomical images with and without contrast agent injection, diffusion imaging and dynamic contrast enhanced-MRI.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 6 Month after the end of treatment
primary_outcome.description: Differentiation of malignant from benign neoplasms and progression free survival at 6 month starting from end of chemo-radiation treatment

intervention.description: You are being asked to complete one research MRI scan with and without contrast at least 24-48 hours after your clinical MRI/CT has shown the presence of a suspicious salivary gland tumor, prior to your scheduled upcoming surgery. MRI contrast agents act like a dye to make MRI pictures brighter and easier to read. During each MRI scan, you will have an intravenous line (IV line) placed. The IV line allows the contrast agent to be injected into your vein. A urine pregnancy test will be conducted for those of child bearing age to confirm eligibility for this study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Possess a salivary gland lesion of 1cm3 size
- Have no prior history of treatment for salivary gland lesion
Exclusion Criteria:
- Has any prior history of cancer other than SGT
- Has any major medical disorder such as poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, or hypertension
- Has history of prior radiation to head and neck region
- Is pregnant
